paragraphs.paragraph: Luis and Mª Lourdes Pérez Molina form an outstanding piano duo, recognized for their performances at both national and international levels. The siblings studied at the Liceu Conservatory of Barcelona, the Franz Liszt Academy in Budapest, and the Manhattan School of Music in New York, where they earned a Master’s and a Doctorate in Musical Arts.

Throughout their professional careers, they have toured in countries such as Spain, Italy, Switzerland, Hungary, Bulgaria, the United States (New York, New Jersey, Illinois, Missouri, Connecticut, Wisconsin, and Florida), and Colombia (Bogotá, Cali, Medellín, and Bucaramanga).

As soloists, they have collaborated with orchestras such as the Barcelona Symphony Orchestra and National Orchestra of Catalonia, the European Union Chamber Orchestra, the Florida Philharmonic Orchestra, the Royal Philharmonic of Galicia, the 'Soloists of Catalonia,' the “Valle del Cauca” Symphony Orchestra, and the “Julià Carbonell” Symphony Orchestra, under the direction of renowned conductors such as Antoni Ros Marbà, Christian Zacharias, Francesco Belli, Matthias Wollong, Virgínia Martínez, Alfons Reverté, ...

The duo has recorded several CDs (The Two Pianos in the 20th Century, Fantasies for Piano Duo, etc.), and has made numerous recordings for radio and television in Spain and abroad. Additionally, they have received multiple chamber music awards, including the first prize in the 5th Permanent Competition of Spain’s Jeunesses Musicales, the second prize in the 2nd Yamaha Competition, the special prize 'Friends of Mozart' in the International Chamber Music Competition in Paris, first prize in Finale-Ligure (Italy), second prize in Caltanissetta (Italy), and the third prize in the International “Dranoff” Two-Piano Competition in Miami. In 1993, they won the “Artists International Auditions” and made their New York debut at Carnegie Hall’s Weill Recital Hall, marking a significant boost to their careers.
The Pérez Molina siblings have also conducted valuable research into the literature for two pianos and piano four hands.
